description.text:
This is a small replacement clip that fits in the slots inside metal cabinets--including the IKEA PS series metal lockers--that shelves rest upon.
Version B is on it's side and needs to print with raft and support.
Version C is rotated to print raftless. (This is the version I printed and used in pictures).
More back-story and photos here: http://wp.me/p2hTaI-21
Print raftless (Version C), if possible. This prints a little thick, though it does hold in place very securely. Sand the narrow section if too thick for your liking.

description.text:
Mounting brackets for Adafruit's Neopixel Rings. 
These are designed for use with 3mm plastic offsets.  
The Top, Bottom, and Top_Offset should work with all sizes of NeoPixel Rings.  The Fixture is designed to be used with the 12 LED ring.  The tabs line up with the 2 via's and Out port on the ring.   If you're using the Out port, this won't work.  The Top_Offset is designed to be standalone if you don't plan to use the bottom or the fixture (ie, you're mounting it to a wall or something where you don't need to have it raised off the surface).
Included is a drill guide, for the 12 LED ring Fixture, but it may be easiest to just print the fixture and use that as a drill guide.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0Qt2F5zNWDh

This was made so that all the terminals are insulated and also helps with the mounting of the socket which is now less likely to split around the bolts on the perspex sheet. Changed slightly from the actual item shown because i forgot to make space for the nuts.

GPZ 500 1st Gen Mirror extension
I have a GPZ 500 and the stock mirrors are terrible. you have to lift up your arm to see whats behind you. I designed and printed this bracket to extend and raise my stock mirrors. It works great and I can now see behind me at all times. Mine are printed in white which suits the bike as it's blue and white but black would probably suit most other colour bikes.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used 0.2 mm

Infill:

I used 20%

Notes: I used PLA as it's what I had in the printer but ABS might be more suited to the job. If you have no problems with warping then I would advise using a higher infill than 20% but I can't go higher than 20% or I end up with a banana shaped bracket. Just print 2 of these brackets. Then take out the 2 screws beneath the rubber shroud that hold the mirror in place. Get 2 longer M6 screws (mine were 60mm long). Replace the mirrors using the bracket and the longer screws. If you use regular M6 X 60 bolts you will need to cut a slot in the end of them with a dremel to screw them in with a flat head screwdriver as the bolt head goes into the recess on the mirror bracket. I would advise trying to find M6 screws if you can.

title: Light-Duty Pliers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Makerbot-printable pliers for light-duty uses.  Designed to be useful for holding small things during inspection, or simply doing things fingers can not.
There is a male arm, a female arm, and a printable nut.  The female swivels around the male, and the nut constrains the assembly.  The geometry of the threads are based on the connections seen in the toothbrush holder and originally in the screwable jewelry box. ( www.thingiverse.com/thing:899 , www.thingiverse.com/thing:413 )
Alternatively, if the design is too optimistic, you can try printing two female arms and use a small screw and nut to hold it together.
All three pieces combined use a total of 1.24 cubic inches of material.

The part is 98mm long, so be sure the build platform is properly centered.
  • Print.
  • Enjoy.
  • Critique.

comments.text: Is this a paralell plier?
comments.author: 3runo

comments.text:
This is a great model! My only complaint is that the threaded nut is a very optimistic part. I look forward to the day when I can tune my makerbot finely enough to make those work as-is. I had to print a 90%-rescaled version of the nut to make it fit.
Also, my makerbot's build platform is a tiny bit off-center from the build envelope, so the handle got clipped a little. This helped me find a build mistake on my part, so kudos for that too!
comments.author: sparr

comments.text: It's really hard to resist the urges to print everything at first, but good settings will pay off in the long run. I recommend skeinforge 006 with default makerbot settings as a good place to start. (http://blog.makerbot.com/2009/11/03/skeinforge-0006/http://blog.makerbot.com/2009/... ) Also, there are lots of parts on thingiverse tagged with "calibration" to help you tune thing up. Good Luck!
comments.author: sparr

comments.text:
I started with skeinforge v6 and the default makerbot settings. I ran into problems printing some calibration items due to firmware bugs (can't print long filenames from SD, wish I had discovered that MUCH sooner).
Why version 6, though? I just discovered the newer skeinforge versions, and they have some amazing options (like printing loops before perimeter, that should help a LOT on tough overhangs).

The coat hanger is made to be used on an internal door which only has about 3mm hardboard surfaces. That is why there are six screws used on this, it is mounted without any other type of fixings than the screws. No support is needed when printing that is included in the file although a raft is useful. The Castor cups were made as a replacement to some that i purchased which had sharper corners at the bottom and were without an inner ring. So that when i moved my bed only a short distance they dug into the soft carpet nearly all came off.
Printing should be 100% infill as they will take a lot of pressure on a small area.

Here is the Universal Lazy Susan There were several other lazy susans already present but some required other parts (bearings, marbles, pellets, etc.,)...some have been design but never tested...and I wanted to learn and get some practice/experience around building my own gears. Plus, having something that is entirely built from 3d prints is just too stickin' cool. This is a pretty versatile lazy susan and can be used with or without the gears.
This can be used with a single gear for easy scrolling.
This can be used with multiple gears for scanning/painting.
This can also be used with modular attachments for various purposes. It is all up to the user on what is desired =) Video of the different methods of using this and some explanation around the whole thing =)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tQPbVSLmk6o

description.text: My mom came with a great idea to make something you only can print and not just make with clay or something, She thought about a owl with seethru body where u can see the egg. Is searched the Thingeverse for a good owl and came across MustangDave his Owl Statue with had a really nice big body where i could make the seethru body. I made he body vonoroi so you can still see the egg. MustangDave 's owl had originally more polygons, but i really like the low poly style so i lowered the poly count. No
You can cut the little cilinder underneath the egg, so it can freely move. also you can make the owl without the egg and put somthing else inside or an egg with a diffrent collour.

. The polycount are lowered with Zbrush to my likings, the vonoroi look was made with Meshmixer and combined with 123D Design, where i cut out the hole in the owl's stomage and merges the two owls together. and put a little egg inside

title: Folding EDF adapter for RC mini gliders (27mm EDF)

description.text:
This adaptor implements a folding EDF (27mm inner diameter) for powering RC mini gliders. I made it for a "Multiplex Solius Mini" but it should fit in most any foamy glider of similar size. 
The EDF pulls itself upright when power is applied and folds back into the fuselage by its own weight / cable pull when it is turned off - no extra servo needed. Total weight of my sample setup is 18g (adaptor + micro EDF) with a model AUW of 96g. Static thrust is about ~60g with a 27mm / 11000kV micro EDF @ 2S 200mAh Lipo battery.

title: Torch display pillar for bigger little pumpkins

description.text: Technically not a remix, but I wanted to light Davidson3d's pumpkins. Unsatisfied with an LED, I found a torch I bought from Maplin (see below) and then tried to work out a way to make it a pillar. With the torch ends, you can use this to uplight any object, they just press fit on the ends of the torch leaving the button and LED's accessible. You can even add a colour gel if you have one - 28-30mm diameter circle. The torch has a burn time over 24 hours with the supplied batteries Here is the torch: http://www.maplin.co.uk/p/9-led-rubber-torch-a78rn

Doesn't Matter

0.2mm

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Print 2 stand parts and one pumpkin seat in black, and the Little Pumpkins in Dutch Orange at 200% size. Glue (yes, I said glue - didn't have time to build a screw option) a seat to a torch end and stick the pumpkin on. If you use 100% infill the light will not get out and you won't see the infill... but the pumpkins will weigh a lot. Between 41 and 62 grams for the ones I printed out.

author: nigeljohnson73

description.text:
This is my CORE XY box printer, with as few as 10 parts, (really 6 parts, 4 parts printed twice!!) I have designed this to be truly simple,
Needing only a hand drill, and a few drill bits,
screwdriver, saw, and a good ruler. And most important super cheep,
All the parts I have designed, to minimize construction complication. and almost any lengths (pairs - especially for X & Y) of 8 mm smooth rod. And no expensive 20*20, maker-beam, aluminium extrusions etc. A video of an early test: https://goo.gl/photos/ZvNmUdDvC9jRPmzk7 Although, with all the money you save, I would recommend getting a genuine E3D hot end. More info in a day or two. If you live in Swansea, then the prototype is in Swansea Hackspace,
http://swansea.hackspace.org.uk/

Step 1: using one of the other sheets of wood, mark up perfectly parallel lines. Build up the box, I used a 'Shelf-pack' from B&Q, for £18,
about 1/4 of the cost of a sheet of contiboard, of similar area.
If anyone knows of an IKIA shelf pack, then let me know, I did have enough IKIA shelves to make a really compact version of this, but they got used for something else, about a week before I started building this. And as a bonus, perfectly square sides, and 18 mm thick. and much better quality 'wood'. a few screws, and small corner brackets (yes, I should of printed them, but I had them anyway). The only really complicated part is setting up the Z mounts,
They have to be parallel in two dimensions,
But if you use a spare shelf, then place it on-top, of the one you are marking out,
align the dimension, then make sure the overlapping edges are flat,
you have a perfect square line. As for the X-Y gantry, Assemble the parts, without any belts,
place on the top, approximately where you want it to go,
Double and tipple check that the print head can reach all four corners of the heated build plate,
then, lightly mark the screw holes.
Using your GOOD ruler (metal one if possible), measure from the front,
and sides,
making sure that the holes to be drilled are EXACTLY the same distance from front, and sides (same for the back) mark the holes, for the four outermost drill holes. check again it slides, and no collisions etc.
Drill one hole, screw it down, check again ...
if all good, drill and screw down (I recommend only screwing down the 4 outermost for the minuet, Now mark where to cut the cutout, I cut out only the minimum,
with just enough to get my fingers down gap. More info later,
and hopefully photos etc.

title: Han Solo in Carbonite - Raspberry Pi 2/B+ Case

description.text: Frozen in Carbonite by Darth Vader, Han Solo has been traded half-way across the galaxy to ultimately serve you as a budget microcomputer! My love of Star Wars brought me to remix these two excellent models into this stellar Raspberry Pi 2/B+ case! Many thanks to Geoffro & aurelius for the original models. Here's a time-lapse that includes my printing technique for this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pwiPxT9yCPo Enjoy! Bleep bloop, Rigelbot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Split: 0.200 for the case, 0.050 for Han Solo

Infill:

30% Fast-Honeycomb

Notes: Printer: Makergear M2
Slicer: Simplify3D
Filament: Hatchbox Silver PLA 1.75mm Settings:
Hotend: 210°C
Heated Bed: 70°C
Split: 200 microns for the case, 50 microns for Han Solo
Adhesion: gluestick on glass + thin layer of hairspray Technique:
At the 30 second mark (in the video), I had the GCODE pause with this: G28 X0; home x-axis
M0; pause Then I flipped the upper section on top of the lower section for the extruder to print Han Solo; effectively avoiding using supports. This saved about an hour of printing and nearly half the material weight.

This is the third version of my E3D mount for my Folger 2020 i3. It works with the MK9 extruder which is shipped with more recent versions of the kit. The MK9 is fractionally taller than the MK7 used in earlier versions. The changes are:
  • move the screw holes up fractionally and so create a little more clearance for the top of the E3D (actually an E3D lite6).
  • remove some extraneous material.
    • I have successfully fitted this with the MK9 as shown in the photo. The tolerances are quite tight, so I don't guarantee it will work for everyone. I needed to put a couple of washers between the motor and the MK9 to get the front-to-back positioning exact. It will work with the MK7 in the same way Supersedes two earlier designs: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1030184 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:990300.

comments.text: Had to sand it down slightly to get the extruder hole to line up with the hotend, but otherwise works great. Used on an e3d lite6 and Folgertech Prusia 2020 i3.

description.text:
Driven by a need to connect my DIY dust extractor to woodworking equipment I created this project to allow me to connect flexible vacuum cleaner hoses to a port, allowing me to switch between different equipment easily by screwing/unscrewing different hoses. I am grateful to CrisHerman for his help in modifying his design, which I was able to embed in my project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1057932 Uses stand 1.25in vacuum cleaner hose which you can buy in bulk from ebay: http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Generic-Black-1-1-4-X-50-Vacuum-Cleaner-Hose-/190535342430 This hose connector requires 5 components: 1) vacuum_cuff.stl: This left-handed cuff screws onto the vacuum hose - pass the hose thru the sleeve first!
2) vacuum_sleeve.stl: Holds the cuff+hose onto the connector lid.
3) vacuum_thru_hole_ring.stl: Passes thru the hole in the vacuum_lid_with_hole, to which the vacuum_sleeve is attached. Note 4x vertical holes are dimensioned to accommodate M3 Nutserts if you wanted to attach different hose designs (optional - you don't need these nutserts if you are using the sleeve in this design.
4) vacuum_lid_with_hole.stl: This screws onto the vacuum_connector_plate_a.
5) vacuum_connector_plate_a.stl: Plate onto which vacuum_lid_with_hole screws to allow quick connection/release. Note that A and B versions are supplied, depending upon your need (you don't need to print both!). I have included vacuum_lid.stl, which allows the use to cap a hose connection, could be useful if you needed to close a connection (you could have multiple connections in parallel within your workshop, where only one was operational at a time. Note that the plate designs are duplicated - use the one with lily pads on the corners to prevent lifting - these pads can be cut off with scissors on completion. Plates also contain structure for marking/drilling vacuum hole - these structures should be snipped off once the holes in the support material have been marked/drilles (before mounting the plate).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes: Don't use supports as these would interfere with holes and threads - supports are not required.

Cut off lily pads with scissors (if lily pad design was used).
Cut off centre structure from plate after holes have been marked/drilled in host panel.

My wife was always complaining about how she could never remember which chain to pull to turn the light on with the ceiling fan, so I decided to make something to help her remember.  I found several chain pulls but liked the one ggangemi had.  I just wanted to make it in more than one color.  Splitting it would make it easier to print and allow each part to be printed in a different color.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: I used a brim on the bulb portion for extra stability when printing.

To assemble, I attached a beaded chain connector to the end of a length of beaded chain. I filled the hole in the bulb portion with a super glue gel and inserted the connector into the bulb. Make sure the connector is completely inside the bulb part. I threaded the chain through the base and added a drop more glue and set it in position, This locks the chain in the pull since the hole in the base is smaller than the bulb and it traps the connector between them.

comments.text: Excellent, I can never remember which is which at Grandpa's, so guess what he's getting for Christmas. :)

I made this for a walk-in shower door handle that kept hitting the tile wall behind it, thus chipping the wall. Now the bumper hits the wall, which is "softer" than the metal, and no longer chips the tile. It is a very tight fit over the handle, which is desired. Once in place, it can turn around the handle if needed to get the best angle against the wall behind the door. Story here: http://wp.me/p2hTaI-2g
Print raftless, if possible. Finish as desired, or leave raw as a testament to the power of printing things at home.

remixed_from.author: eliscott02
remixed_from.title: LeapFrog Creatr Extruder Modifications for NinjaFlex Rubber Filament

description.text:
This is a mount for the flexible-filament remix of the Leapfrog creatr extruder by eliscott02. I remixed it for printing flexible filaments on a reprappro mendel tricolor with a j-head hotend.
This extruder prints filaflex (84A) pretty well, which is supposedly 1 shore softer than ninjaflex (85A). I print filaflex at 240 dC at 40mm/s, 125% extrusion. I set Esteps/mm to 96 in firmware. I have occasional inconsistencies in extrusion, I actually notice a decrease in printability at a lower speed, possibly due to heat creep on the j-head. I haven't yet retrofitted a fan for the j-head. Otherwise, it's been quite reliable.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35

Building the extruder I used a spring from local hardware store, it was approximately 1.5" long, 3/8" wide, and 0.04" wire gauge. I cut the spring down to 1" to adjust the arm tension. I used an Mk7 drive gear for 1.75mm filament, mounted backwards from the creatr leapfrog extruder instructions. I used an M4 bolt for the idler bearing, tap the arm with an M4 tap for the bolt to thread into. I used a 624zz bearing for the idler bearing and sandwiched it between two m4 washers. I used an mkV j-head from hotends.com and modified a little aluminum plate i made earlier to sandwhich the j-head against the extruder body for a tight slop-free fit. I used a 5/8" endmill to carve up the slot where the j-head fits into, otherwise its a lot of filing because I accidentally undersized the dimensions for my 3D printer. I used one m3 bolts to mount the arm to the body and motor and another m3 bolt for the motor. I bored out the filament hole with a 2mm drill bit and bored out the tube hole above the jhead with a 4.2mm drill bit. I cut a piece of 4mm OD teflon tubing to fit up inside the body and mate perfectly with the j-head. The tube goes down into the j-head about 8mm.

Fusion 360 from Solidworks files I imported the SLDPART files from reprappro mendel tricolor github and leafrog extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:321258) and exported them as a STEP file into fusion 360. That's where my design partner, Steven Fan and I from http://hedron.technology/people did the remix magic.

comments.text: I just tried to print ABS with this extruder in a heated build chamber. I noticed the bottom of the PLA body starting to soften. Be sure if flexpla and ABS is your intended application that you print the extruder out of ABS.

author: Shrodix

description.text: Satellite view of the Hurricane Patricia over the cost of Mexico. 3D file generated from a picture on embossify Then we took the Mesh and clean it a little bit so you can see the south of Baja California on the top right corner This project is a manipulative for kids to understand meteorology and to show the nature and formation of storms and phenomenon that is quick and difficult to understand for a kid.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200

Infill:

3%

Notes: Print on a DittoPro at 120 mm/s
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/REiHs1eUi5s" ></iframe>

You can replicated this model with any picture of a storm you like. You just need a good
picture of the storm you like to make a 3D model out of. You then upload the file to embossify and generated the STL. At this point you could pay the 5$ fee to have a higher resolution model that is optional You then upload your model in the slicer software of your choice and print it on your 3D printer.

Objectives: Students will learn the physical aspect of a storm. Research atmospheric phenomenons from our planet and visualize details of the atmosphere from the perspective of space. Audiences: 3rd to 5th grade Preparation: Students will need research any storm of their choice, they have to know the conditions in which a storm is form, they can make a list of the last 10 or more notable storms in the area and research their intensity. Students have to know how the storms are name and why and how a storm intensity is measure. Steps.

  • Start the project by letting students investigated notable storms that hit the area. Have them research their names and their intensity.

  • Make a list of all the storms the students came up with in their research.

  • Assign each student (or pair of students) a storm form the list they research. Make each student look for satellite images of the storm they where assign. Choose 5 photos and save them on your computer

  • Using the webpage embossify teach the students to upload an generated an stl file of the storm they where assign. Students should covert to stl all five pictures they choose in step 3 and save each individual stl file with the name of the storm and the number of the picture.

  • Using the slicing software of your 3D printer make students upload each model from step 4. They have to choose one of the 5 models to print. This could be whatever model they like the best, where you can see the storm arms and storm eye more clearly, or the one that have distinct geographical features.

  • Print each model.

  • While each model is being print (supposing it could take more that a day) Have students prepare a small presentation of each storm. They can focus their presentation on the economical or social impact of the storm and complement their presentation with ground images of the storm.
    • Results: At the end students can look at all the storms in other of intensity and examine physical aspect of the storm. They can touch and make a list of the different characteristics of the storms depending on their intensity.

Flip the model 180 before printing because I'm not the smartest crayon in the box.
Update:  updated model v3 to v4.  I broke a v3.  V4 added some features to strength part. 
Update Update:  Model v9 was added.  After almost snapping my antenna mount off, I tilted back the model and added an "sma protector".   It also has the mount holes as thru-holes so you can zip ties or means of securing.
Another update:  It was brought to my attention that the flat on the right post was not desired.  The original file has it there to make clearance if you were mount an XT60 connector through the top of the frame.  If you're not, I've added a version that does not contain the flat. Enjoy!

comments.text: I took my tweaker out for her maiden flight today with the mount.  After a few crashes, the cricket was ripped off the mount because the screws are just digging into the plastic.  To fix it I used a knife to dig the holes all the way through and attached it with zipties, which seems like a much better solution.  Would you be up to making a new version where the holes go all the way through (or a slot for an M3 nut).  If not, I'll be happy to make a remix :)

This is one of those things that break all the time. Small wind, window force shuts, curtain comes down because one of the holders broke again...
You'll need some kind of thick wire or a small nail for the pin (hole is about 2mm, if printed with shrinking material a bit smaller). I used AWG-13 copper wire (up to AWG-15 should work too but you would have to glue it in)
Just put some double sided tape on the back and stick it to the window frame.

UPDATE - There is a new version for 3.5" propellers: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1274656 UPDATE - There is a new V2 version with many improvements, especially:
  • heavily reinforced arms and base
  • square design (motors on roll & pitch axis are equidistant), MTM is therefore 155
  • LED plates between arms in front and rear part (30x7 mm, e.g Diatone led for ZMR250 will fit this space)
  • thicker spacers
    • Red Dwarf is a micro/mini 135/155 size FPV indoor/outdoor racing quad which is easy to print & build and very funny to fly due to its size and agileness. You can squeeze it through every hole :) It is designed to be one of the smallest and lightest frames that accommodate 3" propellers and standard size components like 1306 motors or CC3D atom flight controller board. Here is a sample video from one of my flights to show that it really flies very good: https://youtu.be/3uZTKIl4EOc. It's capable to carry HD camera for recording like Mobius or even Gopro/SJCam. Video from this maiden flight is raw FPV video captured in my Skyzone 3D Goggles. We also tried some indoor racing: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qn6DaZgi6AA. When printed in ABS with 100% infill it's also rigid and will survive many crashes. Total frame weight is about 32 grams (ABS, 100% infill, M2 self-tapping screws), AUW with FPV gear and 3s lipo 500 mAh is about 200 grams. My recommended setup:
    motors: 4x 1306 3100kv (http://www.banggood.com/DYS-1306-3100KV-BX-Series-Brushless-Motor-For-Multicopter-CW-CCW-p-962149.html)
    ESCs: 4x DYS SN16A (or similar size and amps) (http://www.banggood.com/ZTW-Spider-Series-18A-OPTO-ESC-With-SimonK-Oneshot-Program-p-983660.html)
    flight controller: CC3D Atom (http://www.banggood.com/OpenPilot-CC3D-Atom-Mini-CC3D-FPV-Flight-Controller-CC3D-EVO-p-970762.html)
    propeller: 3045 bullnose (buy 4045 and cut it to 3") (http://www.banggood.com/2-Pairs-Gemfan-4045-ABS-CWCCW-Propeller-For-Mini-Quadcopter-Multirotor-p-975231.html or http://www.banggood.com/Gemfan-3030-ABS-Propeller-Prop-2CW2CCW-4-PCs-For-RC-Quadcopter-p-1005548.html)
    battery: 3S LiPo 500-900 mAh (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__25505__ZIPPY_Compact_500mAh_3S_35C_Lipo_Pack.html)
    FPV camera: mini PZ0420 (or Eachine700tvl) (http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-700TVL-2_6mm-Lens-1-3-CMOS-110-Degree-FPV-Mini-Camera-p-991027.html)
    video TX: FT951 25mW (http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-ET25-5_8G-32CH-25mW-7-24V-Super-Light-Transmitter-p-991026.html, http://www.banggood.com/5_8G-Circular-Polarized-LHCP-Antenna-Short-SMA-RP-SMA-p-965219.html) This 3S setup has very high power to weight ratio and flies really well. Software:
    BLHeli14.1 firmware for ESCs + Damped Light mode + Oneshot125
    Cleanflight 1.10 Luxfloat controller PIDs:
    roll/pitch: 2, 0.040, 30
    yaw: 6, 0.040, 5
    looptime: 1600 There is also a bigger version for 4" propellers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1003801) and 5" propellers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1069161). Have fun!

title: Printrbot Laser Cut Build Platform By Beardface

description.text:
This is exactly the same Laser Cut Build Platform designed by Beardface for 8x8 inch heated bed (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17717) but converted to PDF and rotated & centered to fit A3 paper in landscape if you want to print it and use as a template. Beardface states that this is for Printrbot+ but I will be using it on my Printrbot original with wider spaced bases and an 8 inch heat bed (as seen on the earlier Printrbot build videos by Brook Drumm on YouTube http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6swI8Mer_yw&list=PLDEB12F986EC83054 ). To widen a Printrbot original to accomodate this build platform you will need to fit 4x threaded rods on the bases that are 305mm long and X-axis smooth rods that are 332mm long. Full metric BOM for Printrbot original to suit this build platform is here:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AqAQZ3EWh53GdHc3dlNzZFZwNU1KbWJGdlNRX2RCcEE#gid=0 You may also want to print a couple of feet to improve stability when using the larger build platform, something like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36269
or
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23889 Suggested thickness and material for this thing is 6mm Beech Ply. All credits to Beardface for the original design.
Converted from Beardface's original .dxf files to PDF using Inkscape and CutePDF writer.

Much has changed in the design of the mobile lab after a year or so of the 2.0 release.
Mine has been strapped to tripods / thrown in backpacks / abused by teens learning basic arduino. Features: It holds an Altoid tin for all your electronic Do-Dads. Making it easy to come up with labs that are contained per container by the instructor. (Just better learn to love Altoids). The Altoid tin is held in by elastic bands and a sling. You can remove and put back the tin within a second. Wire management so when you close it your experiment stays put. Expansion- Not tall enough? Add another side piece and it becomes taller (3 is the bare minimum) I hope you enjoy version 3. I will be adding the blender file if you wish to add to the design. Here is a video of it in action
http://youtu.be/qCXab0j_oVM Don't have a 3D Printer? Want to support the product?
Its on sale here.
http://www.etsy.com/listing/155078900/arduino-mobile-lab-30

How to make PLA spikes and rivets here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WqNxYHWpYko I used elastic cord around 1.75mm round for the Altoid sled.
Looks like this. http://www.joann.com/dritz-round-cord-elastic/prd2904/ It is pretty common to find.

comments.text: I used a black and decker dremmel-like tool to create the holes for the eyes (used a little pointy burr bit). It's pretty low tech - the battery box is held in with a two little magnets from an old hard drive: one hot glued to the interior of the bird, the other hot glued to the battery box itself. To turn on the eyes, I insert the batteries. The head has a duct-tape hinge on the back of the neck so that it can flip up for battery access. If I had more time, I would add a ridge around the top of the main body section in order to make attaching the head easier and more secure. Note: locating the battery box in the top of the main-body-section of the bird helps it to balance properly on its feet.

title: Filament Spindle Bushing and Lock Collar

description.text: A spindle bushing and locking collar which will allow standard filament spindles to be easily mounted on a 1 inch wooden dowel.  Loose enough that the filament spindle will rotate easily (on the bushing) and allow effortless feed to your makerbot.  I suspend my dowel from both ends attached via plastic chain to the ceiling in my shop.  You could also attach a dowel to a stand.  Easy to change spools as well. 2 Bushings and 2 Locking collars required.  Just drive a screw through the hole in each each locking collar to hold them in place.  Unscrew and release one side when its time to change filament.

title: Bottom Bracket for Ironing Board Door Hanger

description.text:
Over-the-top door hangers for ironing boards are great. But opening and closing the door causes the ironing board to swing and bump the door annoyingly.  
This accompanying bracket is designed to fit the bottom leg of the ironing board into so it won't swing and bump annoyingly.

I used a caliper to measure how far out from the door the bottom foot of the ironing board goes, used that measurement to design a rounded cuff to fit it into to prevent it from swinging out when the door is used. I extruded it, put in two screw holes and there is also a bit of support at the back for the curve for stress.

author: Baker762

description.text: This is a remix of @friloba's 360 video gopro rig (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:786705) - Thank you @friloba! I've reused his E.Single_case and E.Single_lever components and designed a different core that is a square cube instead of rectangular with slots that are easier to position the cases in. You will need to print one core, six single cases, and six single levers, then glue the cases onto the core cube; the circles are where the GoPro lenses should align. You will need one 1/4-20 hex nut (or threaded insert) for the tripod mount, and six 4-40 (imperial) or M3 (metric) nuts/threaded inserts with corresponding 10mm long thumb screws to fasten the levers to the cases. Use the soldering technique to melt the nuts into the plastic.
In an attempt to make the core lighter and use less material, I've hollowed out the middle, with the possible risk of reducing the strength of the joints. Let me know which core you prefer.

Cube Core In trying to make the rig more compact (and easier to print without having to print and remove supports) I created a simple 35mm cube core (see 6GoProRig-Mars-Core-Cube-v20.stl). It is just a bit of a brain teaser to figure out the proper arrangement of the six Single Cases on each side of the cube core. This cube core shaves off 3mm from the center on each side. I printed the cube core with 10% infill. With the cube core, you will need to also print the separate stem for the tripod mount: (see 6GoProRig-Mars-Stem.stl) Bottomless Single Cases Further, I modified the Single Case to remove the bottom layer (see 6GoProRig-Mars-Single-Bottomless-v10.stl). You can use this with any one of three cores: the 6GoProRig-Mars-Core-v18.stl or 6GoProRig-Mars-Core-v19.stl for a rig that is 3mm smaller on each side, and using this with the cube core reduces 6mm on each side. I used at least 25% infill on these new Single Cases.

remixed_from.title: MP CNC Dust Shoe / Vacuum Attachment - OLD -

title: Adapter for Vacuum Shoe with DW660 and MPCNC

description.text:
NOTE: This is an old design, dating back to the original version of the MPCNC. If you have an old MPCNC (say, 1.5 to 2 years old), then this might work for you. Otherwise, please search for a more up-to-date design. This is a mashup of the lower clamp of Allted's DW660 mount and PCFlyer's vacuum shoe mount. To use this, replace the lower DW660 clamp with this one, then mount PCFlyer's vacuum shoe to it. The knobs that PCFlyer created don't fit with this, because the clearance is less, but I made some that will work. I'm just a beginner at all this, so most of my stuff is functional but not pretty. I combined the two parts by overlaying them in tinkercad and then cutting away what I didn't need using basic shapes. PCFlyer used clear vinyl around the bottom of his shoe. I tried it but ended up buying a door sweep and modifying it. Here's a door sweep I used: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Frost-King-E-O-1-1-2-in-x-36-in-White-Plastic-and-Brush-Door-Sweep-C35PH/100193136. Here's everything you need: MPCNC: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724999
MPCNC DW660 mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:944952
PCFlyer's Vacuum Shoe: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:927909
1/4-20 knob with trapped nut: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1071520 Here's a video of it working: https://youtu.be/bz4ATc_vDko

author: Porkins

description.text:
This device was inspired by a story of Isaac Newton pressing on his eyes in different ways to see the effect it had on his vision. 
The Ocular Pressure Magnifier requires only a light but firm press up to and around the eye, in order to increase magnification. However, there is a sweat spot that you will have to find, that will be a balance between angle and the pressure that is applied to the area around eye. The focal distance for the best magnification and clarity is about 3 inches between the bottom of the magnifier and item being looked at. Don't get discouraged if you do not get it right away, it will take some time to hone in your hot-spot. 
The increase in magnification can be tested with the "This is a test" image I uploaded.

remixed_from.title: Robo 3d R1 X Axis Stepper Motor Mount For Cable Chain System - Remixed Robo3d

title: ROBO3D Cable Chain (Install without removing wires) + Stepper Motor Mount Update

description.text: You no longer need to remove ANY wires to put this cable chain mod. 2 chain links with alternating open sides, a modified chain end that connects to the Stepper motor mount (more mobility), the other end without a top and a new Stepper motor mount with more space for wires and the nice "R" logo of Robo3D.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

40%

Notes: Pieces to print: 41 19 with open bottom, 19 with open top, 1 longer end link w/open bottom, chain end with open top and Stepper motor mount. (would recommend 2 or 3 more prints of the open top and open bottom links - you might break one while putting them on) You will need a little support on the Stepper Motor mount. Also since the chain links have a small area on the bottom, I would recommend a raft. You don't need to remove any wires, although you will need to remove part of the original black chain cable that comes with the printer. I leave it up 8 inches, then I start the cable chain I created (pic included) You can use the screw holes on the end link or use velcro like I did. Also use twist ties to make sure everything stays in place (don't think I needed it but I like to make sure)

This is a common key decoder, use this to find the key cut code of a key and then use the code to duplicate it. Go to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52761 to duplicate the key. Please read the instructions to use this decoder. The video above will tell you guys how to use a decoder although its not necessary to watch but maybe useful to those who dont understand my instructions. Instructions:
1.Put your cut through the largest gap at the end of the decoder
2.Slide it down until it stops at a number
3.Note down the number
4.Move onto the next gap on the key
5.Repeat the steps until all five cuts (gaps in the key) are decoded.
  • Go to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52761
  • Click on the customizer option above the download button
    8.Type in the code that was decoded earlier in order
  • Look at the model, if it does not look like your original key then try reversing the keys number order. If it still doesnt look similar then go to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cuqEI7VvTcU and watch from 3:00 - 4:00 Anything else is irrelevant to this.
    10.Create and download your key
  • Print it off
  • Try it out! You may need to used a fine file to get it to fit in your lock, personally I've ever had to do this. For me it works straight after I remove it from the build plate
    • THIS DECODER WILL WORK FOR MORE THAN JUST SCHLAGE, IVE USED IT ON MANY OTHER TYPES OF LOCKS. Credit to BosnianBill for the Video Credit to Belfry for making the Key duplicator design
This cut's code is 1 This cut's code is 8 This cut's code is 5 Step 8 Step 7 Finished product

author: PKStudio

description.text:
Calibration Border for Makerbot, optimized leveling The normal leveling is for me not good enough.
I use this file now for all my prints as fine-leveling helper.

For some reason I didn't want to stick the LEDs onto my Z stage with sticky back.  I wanted them to be easily removable for repair or replacement.  So, rather than just stick them to some material that I attached to the z stage, I made this thing.
There are dovetailed slots that you can slide the LEDs into and you don't have to use the adhesive at all (it would probably be trick to use it if you wanted to).
There are slots on either side that go under the extruder mount bolts and one in the back if you want to add another nut and bolt.

Print it.
Test fit the LEDs. It's made to hold 6 at the back and 3 on either side.
You may want to trim a little of the dovetails out near where the wires go to make them tuck in better (I did) It's a little tricky to solder the wires on when it's in there but you don't really have a choice (for 4 of the connections). The back bolt hole is probably unnecessary unless you want it to stay in place when you remove your extruder. You may want to make sure that the bolts still clear the build platform. There is plenty of room on my machine but I'm not sure if they are all the same...

This model can be used as a starting point for making a two piece mold that can be used to cast plaster, Sugru, modeling clay, etc and is part of the Learning In A Makerspace chapter of my new book "The Makerspace Workbench" from Maker Media! Simply open the models in 3D CAD and subtract the desired part. Apply a small amount of petroleum jelly prior to casting and pour away!

title: Springy Apple Cable Savers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The charging/connection cable for the new iPhone 6 / iPad Air is smaller than previous cables and is prone to breaking at the joint between the connector and cable through use. This is a solution to help prevent cables from breaking. 
Unlike alternative methods available to counteract this problem the Springy Apple Cable Saver does not just transfer the flex / break point away from the cable / connector joint to another point further up the cable. 
The Springy Apple Cable Connector all but stops movement in the cable / connector joint area and also controls the degree of curvature in the springy area. This stops kinking / tight curves that can weaken the cable over time. The springy area is 'springy' to make the cable spring back to near straight as much as possible... graduating / minimizing curvature that can result in it breaking.
Three .stl files have been provided. They include the device end only, the usb end only and both ends in one file. 
This prints well on a Replicator 2 / 5th Generation Replicator but the spring and designed in internal support pin may prove challenging for some machines. PLA is recommended to make it really springy when 3 shells and a high percentage of infill is used. 
Hopefully this proves beneficial to lots of Apple device owners...
Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Std / 0.20 mm

Infill:

3 Shells / 75% infill

Notes: Recommend using 3 shells and 75% infill with PLA to ensure the Springy Apple Cable Savers are strong and... springy. Use a Raft for a secure base as this will help ensure the springs print well (although they will always be a bit stringy underneath due to movement and the angle). Do not use support. The required support is a designed in pin up the centre that should push out easily after printing (Refer to images)
Support removal... Refer to the images. The designed in centre support pins should push easily out of the centre. They are necessary to minimise movement of the spring during printing.

However, rotating it on the build plate can help as it changes the tool path. It also sounds like your machine is printing it a fraction small so try scaling it up 2 to 3% as that could make all the difference in your case. Having said that you don't want to scale it up too much or it won't fit correctly. These have printed well for thousands of people so hopefully you can get a good result as well

I'm Building a wind shielding case around my Printer at the moment. It isn't finished yet, but I think the results will be much better. The Filament I used is well known for stability not for flexibility. I'm sure your design would work well on the "right" material. In most cases I need filament, which is not flexible, but this time I'm printing for a friend, who really needed these savers.
My infill doesn't matter, because in my setup all Areas <20mm^2 are always printed solid.
Thanks for your design and help!

description.text: 我是一名大三的本科生，现就读于山东大学的机械设计制造及自动化专业。 2015年4月份，我们在中国众筹网站：http://www.zhongchou.com/deal-show/id-123562 通过众筹的方式完成了这一款打印机的众筹推广。 2014年10月份，我在3D打印吧发布教程贴：http://tieba.baidu.com/p/3356312382。 教大家1000元DIY一台3D打印机。得到一片热议，与此同时，我们的团队，根据爱好者反映的问题，设计了这一款性价比极高的全铝型材的3D打印机。 而今，我们开放了我们的所有文件，SolidWorks 2014的图纸，这些图纸是可以编辑的。您可以根据我们在网站公布的资料和我们的图纸进行采购，制作，我们还希望您发现他的问题并通过您自己的智慧对它进行改进进而分享您的智慧。 I'm a undergraduate students, studying in ShanDong university design manufacturing and automation. In April 2015, we all the raise in China website: http://www.zhongchou.com/deal-show/id-123562 to complete by means of the raise the raise of the printer. In October 2014, in China, I published tutorials posted: http://tieba.baidu.com/p/3356312382. Teach you 1000 yuan DIY a 3 d printer.Get a hot, at the same time, our team, according to the problems, reflect lovers of design that a high cost performance of the whole aluminum 3 d printers. Today, we open our all documents, SolidWorks 2014 drawings, the drawings can be edit.You can according to the information in our website and our drawings for procurement, production, we also hope the problem you found him and through your own wisdom to improve it and then share your wisdom.

our team 我们的团队 我们的团队是一群90后的技术宅，爱科技，爱动手，对于3D打印技术的热爱让我们走到了一起。我们在课余时间设计结构，在周末进行电路系统的调试，与此同时，我们和全国各地的3D打印爱好者通过在线云合作进行产品的设计评估，集结了来自全国各地的智慧与经验，数十次易稿，只为一种可能——立志于设计一款性价比极高，开源并且可以自我复制的3D打印机。 Our team is a group of 90 after a technology curtilage, love science and technology, love, love for 3 d printing let us come together.We design, in their spare time on weekends to debug the circuit system, at the same time, we and the 3 d printing lovers all over the country through online cooperative product design assessment of cloud, assembled from all over the country's wisdom and experience, dozens of Yi Gao, only one possibility - aims to design a high performance to price ratio. Open source 3 d printers and can replicate. our advantages 2020型材板prusa i3与原版prusa i3相比主要有以下优化： 1.2020型材铝框架：材质坚固，结构稳定，克服机身晃动缺陷，完虐一般用几个月就散架的亚克力版本。 2.远程抽丝：为获得速度与精度的最大效益，采用远程抽丝技术，解决韦德等近程挤出速度提高框架晃动的问题，同时提高了打印速度。 3.双风扇设计：单风扇设计无法进行搭桥等悬空打印，而双风扇在一定程度上缓解了这个问题，可以进行短距离无支撑打印。 4.T8丝杆：原版设计为了普及技术，采用低（keng）廉（die）的普通牙条，造成Z轴严重水波纹，为保证打印质量，我们改用T8丝杆，效果良好。 5.Y轴传动更新设计：更改Y轴传动方式，减少不必要空间占用。 6．LCD：增加LCD，可以实现脱机打印，同时支持SD卡。 1.2020 profile aluminium frame: material of solid, stable structure, overcome the fuselage defects, shaking the acrylic version of the abuse of general use probably will fall apart a few months.

  • Remote reel off raw silk from cocoons, the speed and accuracy of maximum benefit for using remote reel off raw silk from cocoons, short-range extrusion speed frame shook with dwyane wade, at the same time improve the printing speed.

  • Double fan design: single fan design to bypass dangling such as print, and double fan to a certain extent, alleviate the problem, unsupported print can be a short distance.

  • T8 screw: the original design in order to popularize technology, adopting low (keng) (die) of normal tooth, Z axis caused by serious water ripple, to ensure the quality of printing, we use T8 screw, the result is good.

  • The Y axis transmission update design: change the Y axis transmission way, reduce unnecessary space.Increases the

  • LCD LCD, can realize offline print, at the same time support the SD card.

description.text: Toothbrush holder

The 'Sormtroopers Key Fob' design is based on the new look Stormtroopers from the 2015 Star Wars movie 'The Force Awakens'.. 
Small and simple two colour print... just pause your machine twice during the print to change from white to back then back to white. Allowing fro a 1mm Raft, start your print with white filament then change to black at 2mm (approx. 37%) then back to white at 5mm (83%) for a two coloured print as shown in the images provided. 
The 'Stormtrooper Key Fob' is the same both sides so is reversible (i.e. Not just a flat underside/back). At standard size it measures 30mm high x 25mm wide (excluding the key ring part) so it doesn't use much filament, prints quickly and doesn't make your key chain bulky. 
Note: If you like this check out all my other fun and practical designs..

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm / Standard

Infill:

3 Shells / 35% infill recommended

Notes: Allowing fro a 1mm Raft, start your print with white filament then change to black at 2mm (approx. 37%) then back to white at 5mm (83%) for a two coloured print as shown in the images provided. Raft recommended but no support required/ If no Raft used change the filament at 1mm / 4mm through the print.

This is a encasement for the BI1 ("body interactor" or "vibration interaction pad"), a simple electronic device which analyses movements (e.g. gestures) and reacts with vibration pattern. It is build on the Arduino platform, communicates wireless with other BI1 and comes with a LiPo battery. The application for this encasement is a vibrator (massage wand). We have started a Indigogo crowdfunding campaign. Get your board and encasemnt now: http://igg.me/at/bodyinteraction http://www.bodyinteraction.com/about
The encasement was designed with Tinkercad and printed by Sculpteo.

I created this case mainly as a challenge. It functions and seems to protect my phone well enough. The included picture is of an earlier prototype that failed, I hastily made amendments to hopefully prevent similar failures before uploading to thingiverse.
One of the main challenges was the lack of a decent base model to base the case off of so I went ahead and created one and included it here, it should provide a nice starting point for others if they wish to design their own cases and holsters.

comments.text: My build is nearly done, now I got some serious issues. The printquality is much poorer than on my printer before. I got big problems printing arcs. A circle isn't anything near to round. what could cause this?
comments.author: altrome

comments.text: Hi kev0,
comments.author: Kev0

comments.text:
Because of your too big tolerances around the 8mm rods and the 14,5mm in the XY claps everything is a bit wobbly. I needed to fix all these points. Now the printer runs perpendicular in the axis. The problem persists.
could you please upload a version of your marlin?
I tried every Steperdriver available TMC2100 and DRV8825 are the same. Belt loose, belt overtight, same..
comments.author: altrome

comments.text:
I don't think that these tolerances cause the problem... but all is possible. As I said, once you place the bearings and tight the screws below, the tolerance disappears... my carriages are not wobbling at all. Printing ovals instead of circles, sounds more like a belt problem... but if you have checked it... I don't know what can cause this behavior. What about the sound while printing? Mine is really silent compared to my other printer a BCN3D.
Sadly I can not upload my marlin right now but as soon as I can I will do it.
comments.author: Kev0

comments.text:
Its relative quiet.
I tightened the belt so much it went off the ball bearings. so tgis cant be the source. I noticed a slight move in Y direction while X is moving. this doesnt look right. How do I manage to solve this? Is this behause of a difference in belt tension? I tried everything I could mention.
comments.author: altrome

comments.text: Mmmm.. ok... I'm aware of that to tighten the belt is the most delicate part.... I usually tighten progressively, alternating right and left. Between each operation I move the carriage to the max and min Y positions and I ensure there is the same distance on the right and on the left ( X perpendicular to Y). The optimal tension is not easy to be explained... not too tight nor too loose... I know that this is not the most rigorous answer, but I think it can help.
comments.author: Kev0

comments.text: Sadly I have to say its a design flaw. Because I have to tighten the 14.5 mm holes of the x-carriage to 14mm the whole carriage got another spacing between the two x rods. Caused by this there is to much friction and I got some minor slipstick effect on the x-axis. All the other axis can be aligned but the distance between the x-axis are fixed  by the xy-carriages. It would be nicer to have realistic tolerances between the rods/mounting points and the bearings/carriages. I'll try to edit your files to something like +0.1 in diameter. Hopefully this will do the trick. Otherwise I think the front left pulley holder must be stiffer, in movement it bends and the y-axis gets pushed down. I printed everything with 30% retangular infill. The other parts seem to be allright. Still a great design!
comments.author: altrome

comments.text: I feel bad that you have this problem. The design has been tested not only by me, but by other users with different printers, and none of the problems you have commented have been appeared before... really strange. I still think that there is some other problem that we are not able to see that is causing this malfunction, but we are focusing only in the effect not the cause. It's a pitty not to have in front the printer so we could investigate further the problem (personally is one of the best parts of the process of making/building a printer, but the most frustrating at the same time). I will be here to help you in all that I can, but with the information I have right now I can't go further. Keep us informed about your advances. Good luck!!
comments.author: Kev0

comments.text:
For now I solved the issue. To fix the slight missalignments I opened the Bushings with a 8F8 bore to have a little mor play. Its good now.
I got some problems with slight bended idler pulleys.I'll construct a upper supportfor each corner.
I made some mods of your parts to have a better fitting (e.g. M3 Nuts not 6mm, 5,5mm holes are the right ones).

This fun little car is designed to expose kids to engineering concepts and is part of the Learning in a Makerspace chapter of my new book "The Makerspace Workbench" from Maker Media! Simply cut out the pieces and glue together.

This is a motor carrier for the AS3XTRA
It allows to use the GPS-C03 motor set with the original shaft and bearings from the AS3XTRA The Motor is from here:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__10003__Micro_Power_system_w_Gearbox_GPS_C03.html
The original gearbox has a terribly soft shaft and the mounting options aren't good as well. The idea is to take the gears and motor form the set and combine them with the shaft and bearings from the AS3XTRA. Everything should then fit into this motor carrier The prop in the picture is this:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__27457__GWS_EP_Propeller_DD_5030_127x76mm_orange_6pcs_set_.html

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.09mm

Infill:

full

Conctruction You have to make sure that the holes are 2.5mm and 7mm respectively. I had to drill mine after printing to get them to the right diameter
Then you have to remove the bigger gear from the GPS-C03 geartrain. It's just friction mounted.
You have to increase the hole from 1mm to 1.5mm with a drill.
Then disassemble the AS3XTRA motor mount. Place the gear on the shaft and put the brass bushings into the printed motor carrier.
Then add the drilled gear on the shaft and fit it into the bushings.
Mount the assembly with the little plastic nut. Careful it is left-threaded.
Next fit the brushless motor. It should fit with good friction.
Last you have to drill the prop adapter to size and mount in front.
The prop should again be friction fitted.

This is a power supply cover for use with my Voxel Ox 8" 3D Printer. It is designed to fit a 12V 30A power supply as sold by OpenBuilds. Other models will probably fit but can't guarantee screw holes will be in exact same position. Mounts securely to PSU with 4 x M4 6mm length. Makes use of switched and fused power inlet module with C14 power cord socket.
Can be found on amazon or ebay.
ex: http://www.amazon.com/Inlet-Power-Socket-Switch-IEC320/dp/B00511QVVK/ 18AWG stranded wires are soldered and heat shrunk onto the power inlet module as pictured and have crimped spade connectors for proper attachment to power supply input terminals. Power supply output is for connecting to a RAMPS board. The wire is jacketed 4 conductor 16AWG wire. For strain relief I use Heyco "RDD 101" Mfg #1852 locking strain relief bushing. http://www.mouser.com/Search/ProductDetail.aspx?R=1852 The use of crimped insulated ferrules allows for a solid connection between the RAMPS screw down terminals and the 16AWG stranded wire. Inside the PSU Cover side all 4 wires have crimped spades as well for secure connection to the power supply terminals. Works great in conjunction with my PSU Bracket for 2020 Aluminum Extrusion
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1091724

description.text:
Hello All, This is a "ziptieless" version of the Rostock Mini Pro vertical carriage that was derived from 3D Printer Czar (which was derived from Johann C. Rocholl classic Rostock design).
The carriage is fastened properly with M3 hardware that is easier to implement and more reliable in the long run by eliminating possible slippage. To be used with the 3D Printer Czar Rostock Mini Pro End Effector/Platform. Made with Tinkercad by simply joining two available .stl files. Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: ProtoBuilds
remixed_from.title: No slip power supply mount clip bracket for any width aluminum extrusion 20mm Openbuilds v-slot / Misumi

description.text:
This is a tweaked version of Protobuilds' design here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:846157 This bracket attaches a 12V 30A power supply to 2020 based aluminum extrusion, such as OpenBuilds V-slot or other. I used it on my Voxel Ox 8" 3D Printer. Works great in conjuction with my PSU Cover here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1091686 Changes made from original:
  • Overhang snaps are little shorter and rounded now, to make it easier to snap power supply in.
  • Added slight taper to the snap to really grip the PSU in place, no movement at all with just a single notched mount bracket.
  • Rotated to the intended orientation for printing
    • Hardware needed:
    2x M5 8mm length bolts
    2x t-slot nuts. Mounting my PSU with a single "notched" version is plenty secure for me. "No notch" version is also provided in case you prefer a two bracket mounting(for 20x40 20x60 20x80 or just two spaced apart 20x20). The no notch can slide along length of power supply to adjust for however your extrusion is spaced. Very simple and effective design.

title: Convert Xiaomi NightVision Wireless IP Cam to Door Viewer

description.text:
Do you want to avoid answering callers at your front door?
Do you want to interact with them remotely?
Do you want extra security?
KickStarter projects too expensive? Too much Hipster BS?
Want something free? (CC-Attribution) Well you can 3D print a housing to mount the Xiaomi IP camera with Night Vision (Xiaomi Ants) at your front door! The camera itself cost roughly £20 (US$30?), and you do need some hacking with the hardware, mainly just soldering skills, extra parts required... Undaunted? Read on! Bill of Material: 1) Xiaomi NightVsion Wireless IP camera http://www.banggood.com/Original-Xiaomi-Xiaoyi-Ants-Night-Vision-720P-Smart-Wireless-Webcam-Security-IP-Camera-p-983655.html 2) Micro USB breakout board, a specific one, dimension is important!
NB: The board is 15x13x1.7mm http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/10PCS-Female-MICRO-USB-to-DIP-5-Pin-Pinboard-2-54mm-micro-USB-type-/141689511537?hash=item20fd5a5e71 3) 4 x 8mm, Countersunk Screw, M3 4) 1 x 30mm, Socket Cap Screw, M3 5) 1x 25mm, Hexagon Stand-off Spacer, M3 6) Almost forgot, 1 x 3mm, M3 screw, preferable flat top to screw Hexagon spacer in place Item 4 and 5 will depend on your door thickness... e.g. Steel Reinforced Meth Lab Void Warranty Section
You have to enlarge the original Mic opening on the camera to allow wiring Don't be a dummy, flip and print largest flat surface down on print bed!!!

Where are the power terminals... Unmodified disassembly Add wiring, enlarge Mic hole, extend Mic wiring Replace camera housing, stuff it into 3D printed housing, note where the Mic is positioned Thread wiring through the housing, screw in back cover. Note Left equal Negative terminal, Right equal Positive terminal, access hole for Camera Reset Put some blu-tak around the back to aide mounting on door and prevent slipping when adjusting and tightening in position Front of door and its back, access is from the original peep hole opening... No soldering required, simply twist and loop securely the striped ends of wires, insert the long 30mm screw and tighten Stuff the excess wiring back into the door peep hole cavity... Snap the cover on, plug-in the USB power, that's it job done!

The digital multimeter series UT71 from UNI-TREND provides a cheap measurement solution with reasonable accuracy. The set includes an USB Interface Cable and a Windows based software. Unfortunately the USB Interface doesn't work with Mac OS X. But the optical interface can be easily soldered for less than 5.00 €.
More detailed description you will find here (http://tech.rbulla.de/doku.php?id=tech:ut71)
Of course one may also use a 3D printer to print the adapter.

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

Notes: I used a laser cut housing based on 2mm white acryl. The design was prepared with Inkscape. Depending on the thickness of your wiring you may not need all layers. In my example I only used 4 pieces. All layers are glued together with a two-component adhesive. Better holding you may get if you glue a half of a drinking straw on the lug as seen on first picture.
Good luck!

I shattered the wheel nut (see picture) and needed a fast replacement. The green is 3D printed one and the black is the original.
This is a replacement 12mm bring-along wheel nut for my 1/10 Stealth X09 Brushless R/C car. I thought it might be used on other models as well, so I wanted to share it with you. It has tight tolerences, so you'll need a well calibrated printer. Print with 0,1mm layers and 100% infill. There are two stl's:
one for a well adjusted printer
one for standard adjusted printers The stl for welll adjusted printers have tight tolerences
The stl for standard adjusted printer have ~10% bigger holes (because circles are really polygons) Note: the model is 10:1 (nut model is 120mm real life nut is 12 mm. Remember to scale it Down.

This is a holding bracket designed to support a phone upright, or a small tablet sideways. It holds the generic circular Wireless Qi Chargers with space for connecting and routing a USB cable. V9 has further cuts to reduce material use, although done in a way to improve prints through less bridging. Print time is now almost half that of previous versions. The Qi Charger is centred at 65mm above the stands - so for optimum results the phone will be around twice that length if the internal charging unit sits half way up your phone. Mine is a Samsung S7 and it works perfectly. The dimensions of the charger that it holds are as follow:
Outer Diameter: 70mm
Depth: 9.8mm All the USB charging cables that I've tried have fitted with minimal persuasion - but I wanted it tight to ensure that it was held securely.

comments.text: Would it work for an iPhone 4s and 5s?
comments.author: Kmaric

comments.text: Unfortunately I couldn't say for sure as I don't have either of them. The latest version of this stand has a centre position of about 63 mm (above the holding step), so ~ assuming the wireless receiver in your phone is centred ~ as long as the height of your phone is near double that, you should be fine. It has worked with all the phones I've tried on it so far - I've even tried charging a 7 inch tablet on it laying in portrait and it is nicely centred and charges effectively.

the cable ties fit all options. Pictured in blue is the predecessor,
which had a snap mount, Although this did work extremely well,
One print, the E3D cooling fan did not come on, and after a little time,
heat built up, and softened the snap-mount,

with two opposing vice grips. Additionally, you can see in the photos an adapter to fit bouden cable, So both types of E3D can be used.

Hi there, 
If you're looking for a home made rod pod this might help you building it. You can use the already printable files from here, or you can remix them as you like.
I did this because i love my 3D printer and since i got it i love doing my own things. Of course i could of bought this rod pod from a fishing store (in my country you can find it for as cheap as 25$) but there is no good feeling like when you build it yourself. The hardware cost me something like 9$ (6$ the M10 threaded rods and 3$ the M10 nuts). 
Hope you like it and enjoy using it.

comments.text: I found the top of the box piece to be too deep.  The bottom part with a bar of soap will almost completely disappear into the top when the two pieces are combined. This makes it very difficult to separate the top from the bottom.  The sides of the top piece should be shallower to allow for easier separation of the two pieces.  Shaving off 1/2" all around will make it much easier to separate.   Another design idea would be to make a slide on lid.
